content.description: Figure 1 represents a metabolic process involving the regulation of lactose metabolism by E. coli bacteria. Lactose is utilized for energy by E. coli when glucose is not present. Allolactose is an isomer of lactose that is in the environment of these bacteria when lactose is present. The <math alttext="C A P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CAP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> site prevents the binding of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase when glucose is present in the environment. The <math alttext="lac Z" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>l</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>Z</mi></mrow></math>, <math alttext="lac Y" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>l</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>Y</mi></mrow></math>, and <math alttext="lac A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>l</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></math> genes code for proteins needed for lactose metabolism.
content.question: Figure 1. Model of lac operon, comparing repressed and active states Which is a scientific claim that is consistent with the information provided and Figure 1 ?

choices.label: The presence of excess lactose blocks the functioning of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase in this operon.
When bound to the operator, the repressor protein prevents lactose metabolism in E. coli.
The binding of the repressor protein to the operator enables E. coli to metabolize lactose.
Allolactose acts as an inducer that binds to the operator, allowing E. coli to metabolize lactose.

content.answer: When bound to the operator, the repressor protein prevents lactose metabolism in E. coli.
